_link.title: I can identify valence electrons from an electron configuration

options.text: The electrons in the outermost shell of an atom
The electrons in the innermost shell of an atom
options.explanation: Inner-shell electrons are called core electrons; valence electrons are in the outermost shell.

options.text: All the electrons in an atom
options.explanation: Valence electrons are only those in the outermost shell, not all electrons.

options.text: The electrons in the nucleus
options.explanation: Electrons are not in the nucleus; valence electrons are in the outermost electron shell.

toLevel2.question: An atom has the electron configuration 2, 8, 1. How many valence electrons does it have?

options.explanation: 2 is the number of electrons in the first shell; the outermost shell has 1 electron.
8 is the number of electrons in the second shell; the outermost (third) shell has 1.
11 is the total number of electrons; valence electrons are only those in the outermost shell.

toLevel2.question: An atom has the electron configuration 2, 6. How many valence electrons does it have?

options.explanation: 2 is the number of electrons in the first (inner) shell; the outermost shell has 6.
8 is the total number of electrons, not the valence electrons.
This atom has 6 electrons in its outermost shell; only noble gases with full outer shells are sometimes described as having 0 or 8 valence electrons.

toLevel2.question: An atom has the electron configuration 2, 8, 7. How many valence electrons does it have?

options.explanation: 8 is the number of electrons in the second shell; the outermost (third) shell has 7.
2 is the first shell; the valence electrons are in the outermost shell (7).
17 is the total electron count; valence electrons are only the outermost shell's 7.

toLevel2.question: Which shell contains the valence electrons in an atom with the configuration 2, 8, 8, 2?

options.text: The fourth shell
The first shell
options.explanation: The first shell is the innermost; valence electrons are in the outermost shell, which is the fourth.

options.text: The second shell
options.explanation: The second shell is an inner shell; the outermost (fourth) shell holds the valence electrons.

options.text: The third shell
options.explanation: The third shell is not the outermost; the fourth shell with 2 electrons is outermost.

toLevel2.template: Valence electrons are the electrons in the {{blank:1}} shell of an atom. For configuration 2, 8, 3, there are {{blank:2}} valence electrons.
An atom with electron configuration 2, 4 has {{blank:1}} valence electrons in its {{blank:2}} shell.
To find the number of valence electrons, look at the {{blank:1}} number in the electron configuration. For 2, 8, 5, the answer is {{blank:2}}.

toLevel2.statement: An atom with the electron configuration 2, 8, 4 has 4 valence electrons.
toLevel2.explanation: The outermost shell is the third shell, which has 4 electrons — these are the valence electrons.

toLevel2.statement: An atom with the electron configuration 2, 8, 8 has 8 valence electrons.
toLevel2.explanation: The outermost (third) shell has 8 electrons; these are the valence electrons. This is the configuration of argon.

toLevel3.question: Sodium has the electron configuration 2, 8, 1. Why is knowing its valence electrons important for predicting its chemistry?

options.text: Because valence electrons are the ones involved in chemical bonding and reactions
Because valence electrons determine the atom's mass
options.explanation: Mass is determined by protons and neutrons, not electrons.

options.text: Because valence electrons are in the nucleus
options.explanation: Electrons are in shells around the nucleus, not in the nucleus.

options.text: Because valence electrons cannot be removed from the atom
options.explanation: Valence electrons are the easiest electrons to remove; they participate in bonding.

toLevel3.question: Magnesium (2, 8, 2) and calcium (2, 8, 8, 2) both have 2 valence electrons. What does this tell us?

options.text: They are in the same group and have similar chemical properties
They are the same element
options.explanation: They have different total electrons and different numbers of shells; they are different elements in the same group.

options.text: They have the same number of total electrons
options.explanation: Magnesium has 12 electrons and calcium has 20; only their valence electrons are the same.

options.text: They are in the same period of the periodic table
options.explanation: Magnesium is in Period 3 and calcium is in Period 4; same valence electrons means same group, not period.

toLevel3.question: An element has 7 valence electrons. Which group of the periodic table is it in?

options.text: Group 17
Group 7
options.explanation: Group 7 contains transition metals; main group elements with 7 valence electrons are in Group 17.

options.text: Group 18
options.explanation: Group 18 elements (noble gases) have 8 valence electrons (or 2 for helium), not 7.

options.text: Period 7
options.explanation: The number of valence electrons tells you the group number, not the period.

toLevel3.question: Nitrogen (2, 5) and phosphorus (2, 8, 5) both have 5 valence electrons. Why do they have similar chemical properties?

options.text: Because elements with the same number of valence electrons react in similar ways
Because they have the same total number of electrons
options.explanation: Nitrogen has 7 electrons total and phosphorus has 15; their similar chemistry comes from equal valence electrons.

options.text: Because they are in the same period
options.explanation: Nitrogen is in Period 2 and phosphorus is in Period 3; they are in the same group.

options.text: Because they have the same number of electron shells
options.explanation: Nitrogen has 2 shells and phosphorus has 3; similar properties come from equal valence electrons.

toLevel3.question: Neon has the electron configuration 2, 8. How many valence electrons does neon have, and why is it unreactive?

options.text: 8 valence electrons; its outer shell is full, so it does not need to gain, lose, or share electrons
0 valence electrons; noble gases have no outer electrons
options.explanation: Neon has 8 electrons in its outer shell; a full outer shell makes it stable, not empty.

options.text: 2 valence electrons; only the first shell counts
options.explanation: The outermost shell (second shell with 8 electrons) holds the valence electrons.

options.text: 10 valence electrons; all electrons are valence electrons in noble gases
options.explanation: Only the outermost shell electrons are valence electrons; neon has 8 in its outer shell.

toLevel3.question: For main group elements, what is the relationship between group number and the number of valence electrons?

options.text: The group number's last digit equals the number of valence electrons (e.g., Group 1 = 1, Group 16 = 6)
The group number equals the total number of electrons
options.explanation: Group number relates to valence electrons, not total electrons.

options.text: The group number equals the number of electron shells
options.explanation: The number of shells equals the period number, not the group number.

options.text: There is no relationship between group number and valence electrons
options.explanation: For main group elements, the units digit of the group number matches the valence electron count.

toLevel3.template: Elements in the same {{blank:1}} have the same number of valence electrons, which is why they have similar {{blank:2}} properties.
Noble gases have {{blank:1}} outer shells, typically with {{blank:2}} valence electrons, making them very stable.
For main group elements, the number of valence electrons equals the {{blank:1}} digit of the {{blank:2}} number.

toLevel3.statement: Lithium (2, 1) and potassium (2, 8, 8, 1) have similar chemical properties because they both have 1 valence electron.
toLevel3.explanation: Both are in Group 1 with 1 valence electron, so they react similarly — for example, both react vigorously with water.

toLevel4.question: An unknown element has the electron configuration 2, 8, 8, 1. Predict how many electrons it will lose to form a stable ion.

options.text: 1 electron, to achieve a full outer shell of 8
7 electrons, to match the second shell
options.explanation: Atoms lose or gain the fewest electrons possible to get a full outer shell; losing 1 gives a stable 2, 8, 8 configuration.

options.text: 8 electrons, to empty the third shell
options.explanation: Losing 1 electron from the fourth shell gives a stable configuration; losing 8 from the third is not favourable.

options.text: 0 electrons, because it already has 8 in the third shell
options.explanation: The fourth shell with 1 electron is the outermost; the atom needs to lose this electron for stability.

toLevel4.question: Oxygen (2, 6) has 6 valence electrons. How many electrons will it gain to form a stable ion?

options.text: 2 electrons, to complete its outer shell to 8
6 electrons, to empty its outer shell
options.explanation: Non-metals gain electrons to fill their outer shell; gaining 2 gives oxygen a full shell of 8.

options.text: 8 electrons, to fill a new shell
options.explanation: Oxygen only needs 2 more to complete its outer shell of 8.

options.text: 1 electron, because it only needs one more
options.explanation: Oxygen needs 2 more electrons (8 - 6 = 2) to complete its outer shell.

toLevel4.question: Silicon has the electron configuration 2, 8, 4. A student says silicon will lose 4 electrons. Another says it will gain 4. Who is more likely correct and why?

options.text: Neither is fully correct for simple ions; silicon typically shares its 4 valence electrons through covalent bonding rather than forming ions
The first student is correct; silicon always loses 4 electrons
options.explanation: Losing 4 electrons requires too much energy; silicon typically forms covalent bonds instead.

options.text: The second student is correct; silicon always gains 4 electrons
options.explanation: Gaining 4 electrons is also unfavourable; silicon prefers covalent bonding.

options.text: Both are correct depending on the day
options.explanation: The behaviour is not random; silicon's 4 valence electrons make covalent bonding most favourable.

toLevel4.question: An element in Group 15 has the electron configuration 2, 8, 5. How would this element most likely achieve a stable electron configuration?

options.text: By gaining 3 electrons to complete its outer shell to 8
By losing 5 electrons to empty its outer shell
options.explanation: Losing 5 electrons requires too much energy; gaining 3 is more energetically favourable for non-metals.

options.text: By gaining 5 electrons to reach 10 in the outer shell
options.explanation: The third shell can hold a maximum of 8 electrons (for Period 3 elements), not 10.

options.text: By losing 3 electrons to reach 2 in the outer shell
options.explanation: Having 2 electrons in an outer shell is not a stable configuration for a Period 3 element; gaining 3 to reach 8 is preferred.

toLevel4.question: Aluminium (2, 8, 3) forms Al³⁺ ions. Use its valence electrons to explain why.

options.text: Aluminium has 3 valence electrons and loses all 3 to achieve the stable electron configuration 2, 8
Aluminium gains 3 electrons to become Al³⁺
options.explanation: Gaining electrons would create a negative ion; Al³⁺ is positive, meaning electrons were lost.

options.text: Aluminium loses 8 electrons from its second shell
options.explanation: Aluminium loses its 3 outermost (valence) electrons, not inner-shell electrons.

options.text: Aluminium loses 3 protons to become Al³⁺
options.explanation: Ions form by losing or gaining electrons, not protons; losing protons would change the element.

toLevel4.question: Element X has the electron configuration 2, 8, 8, 7. Predict which group it is in and how it would form a stable ion.

options.text: Group 17; it would gain 1 electron to form an X⁻ ion with a full outer shell
Group 7; it would lose 7 electrons to form X⁷⁺
options.explanation: This element is in Group 17 (not 7), and losing 7 electrons requires far too much energy; it gains 1 electron.

options.text: Group 17; it would lose 7 electrons to form X⁷⁺
options.explanation: Non-metals in Group 17 gain electrons; losing 7 is energetically unfavourable.

options.text: Group 18; it already has a stable configuration
options.explanation: 7 valence electrons is not a full shell; Group 18 elements have 8 (or 2 for helium).

toLevel4.question: Beryllium (2, 2) and magnesium (2, 8, 2) both have 2 valence electrons. Predict the charge of their ions.

options.text: Both form 2+ ions by losing their 2 valence electrons
Both form 2- ions by gaining 2 electrons
options.explanation: Metals lose valence electrons; with only 2 valence electrons, they lose both to form 2+ ions.

options.text: Beryllium forms 2+ but magnesium forms 2-
options.explanation: Both are metals in Group 2 with 2 valence electrons; both lose 2 electrons to form 2+ ions.

options.text: Both form 8+ ions to empty all their shells
options.explanation: Only valence electrons are lost; both lose 2 electrons, not all their electrons.

toLevel4.template: An atom with electron configuration 2, 8, 2 has {{blank:1}} valence electrons and will {{blank:2}} them to form a stable ion.
Chlorine (2, 8, 7) has {{blank:1}} valence electrons and needs to {{blank:2}} 1 electron to fill its outer shell.
Elements with {{blank:1}} valence electrons (like carbon and silicon) tend to form {{blank:2}} bonds rather than ions.

toLevel5.question: Sulfur (2, 8, 6) and selenium (2, 8, 18, 6) both have 6 valence electrons. However, selenium can expand its bonding capacity beyond what sulfur typically shows. What accounts for this difference?

options.text: Selenium has empty d-orbitals in its outer shell that can accommodate additional bonding electrons, while sulfur in most compounds does not use d-orbitals
Selenium has more valence electrons than sulfur
options.explanation: Both have 6 valence electrons; the difference is in available orbitals, not valence electron count.

options.text: Selenium is a metal and sulfur is a non-metal
options.explanation: Both selenium and sulfur are non-metals; the difference relates to orbital availability.

options.text: Sulfur cannot form any bonds because it is too small
options.explanation: Sulfur does form bonds; it typically forms 2 bonds using its valence electrons.

toLevel5.question: A student claims: 'All elements in Group 14 bond the same way because they all have 4 valence electrons.' Evaluate this claim.

options.text: Incorrect; while all have 4 valence electrons, carbon forms covalent bonds, silicon and germanium are metalloids, and tin and lead can form ionic bonds as metals
Correct; 4 valence electrons always means covalent bonding
options.explanation: Tin and lead are metals that can lose electrons to form ions; bonding type varies down the group.

options.text: Incorrect; only carbon has 4 valence electrons
options.explanation: All Group 14 elements have 4 valence electrons; the statement is wrong about bonding, not electron count.

options.text: Correct; the group number completely determines bonding behaviour
options.explanation: Group number determines valence electrons but not entirely bonding behaviour, which also depends on metallic character.

toLevel5.question: Iron (a transition metal) can form Fe²⁺ and Fe³⁺ ions. Why can't the concept of 'valence electrons = group number' be simply applied to transition metals?

options.text: Because transition metals can lose different numbers of electrons from both their outer shell and inner d-orbitals, giving variable oxidation states
Because transition metals have no valence electrons
options.explanation: Transition metals do have valence electrons; they just have variable numbers they can lose.

options.text: Because transition metals are in groups 3–12 and the rule only works for groups 1–2
options.explanation: The rule works for all main group elements (Groups 1, 2, 13–18); transition metals are the exception.

options.text: Because iron is magnetic and this prevents simple electron counting
options.explanation: Magnetism is unrelated to how we count valence electrons; the issue is d-orbital involvement.

toLevel5.question: Helium has the electron configuration 2. It has 2 valence electrons like Group 2 elements. Why is helium placed in Group 18 rather than Group 2?

options.text: Because helium has a full outer shell (the first shell holds a maximum of 2), giving it noble gas properties like Group 18 elements
Because helium has no electrons
options.explanation: Helium has 2 electrons; its placement is due to its full outer shell and noble gas behaviour.

options.text: Because helium is a gas and Group 2 elements are solids
options.explanation: Physical state is not the reason; the full first shell gives helium noble gas chemical properties.

options.text: Because the periodic table was designed incorrectly
options.explanation: Helium's placement in Group 18 is deliberate because it has a complete outer shell and is chemically inert.

toLevel5.question: An atom has the configuration 2, 8, 18, 8, 2. A student says it has 2 valence electrons and is in Group 2. Another student says it has 8 valence electrons because the third shell has 18. Who is correct?

options.text: The first student is correct; valence electrons are only those in the outermost shell (2), and the atom is in Group 2
The second student is correct; the 18 in the third shell matters
options.explanation: The third shell's 18 electrons are inner electrons; only the outermost (fifth) shell's 2 electrons are valence.

options.text: Both are wrong; the atom has 18 valence electrons
options.explanation: 18 is in an inner shell; valence electrons are the 2 in the outermost fifth shell.

options.text: Neither is correct because this configuration is impossible
options.explanation: This is a valid configuration (e.g., strontium); the outermost shell has 2 valence electrons.

toLevel5.question: Comparing fluorine (2, 7) and chlorine (2, 8, 7): both have 7 valence electrons, but fluorine is more reactive. How do valence electrons and atomic structure explain this?

options.text: Both need 1 more electron, but fluorine's smaller size means the nucleus attracts incoming electrons more strongly, making it more reactive
Fluorine has more valence electrons than chlorine
options.explanation: Both have exactly 7 valence electrons; reactivity differences come from atomic size and nuclear attraction.

options.text: Chlorine has too many inner electrons blocking its reactivity
options.explanation: While inner electrons do shield, the key factor is fluorine's smaller atomic radius increasing electron attraction.

options.text: Fluorine is more reactive because it has fewer total electrons
options.explanation: Fewer total electrons is not the direct cause; it is the smaller atomic radius that strengthens attraction for the incoming electron.

toLevel5.question: A student is told that an atom has 4 valence electrons. They say it must be carbon. Is this necessarily correct?

options.text: No; any Group 14 element (carbon, silicon, germanium, tin, or lead) has 4 valence electrons — more information is needed to identify the specific element
Yes; only carbon has 4 valence electrons
options.explanation: All Group 14 elements have 4 valence electrons; you also need the number of shells to identify the element.

options.text: No; 4 valence electrons is not possible for any element
options.explanation: 4 valence electrons is perfectly normal for Group 14 elements.

options.text: Yes; valence electrons uniquely identify every element
options.explanation: Multiple elements in the same group share the same number of valence electrons.

toLevel5.question: Explain why the number of valence electrons is more useful than the total number of electrons for predicting chemical behaviour.

options.text: Because only valence electrons participate in bonding and reactions; core electrons are held too tightly by the nucleus to be involved
Because the total number of electrons is always the same for all elements
options.explanation: Different elements have different total electrons; the point is that only outermost electrons participate in reactions.

options.text: Because core electrons do not exist; all electrons are valence electrons
options.explanation: Core electrons do exist in inner shells; they just don't participate in chemical bonding.

options.text: Because valence electrons determine the mass of the atom
options.explanation: Mass is determined by protons and neutrons; valence electrons determine chemical reactivity.

toLevel5.template: Valence electrons determine an element's {{blank:1}} behaviour, while the total number of electron shells determines its {{blank:2}} in the periodic table.
Helium is in Group {{blank:1}} despite having only 2 electrons because its outer shell is {{blank:2}}.
